summary: This document is a compilation of news clips from August 20, 2019, covering multiple cases in the Southern District of New York. The primary focus is on the aftermath of Jeffrey Epstein's death, including the motion to drop charges against him, investigations into his co-conspirators, and details about his estate. It also covers separate cases involving Michael Avenatti, John Pierre Dupont, Nicholas Tartaglione, and Jesus Prado.

persons.name: Michael Avenatti
persons.context: Embattled attorney facing federal extortion charges for allegedly threatening Nike Inc. He is also accused of stealing from a client and embezzlement in separate cases.

persons.name: Geoffrey Berman
persons.role: U.S. Attorney for the Southern District of New York
persons.context: Filed a motion to drop charges against Jeffrey Epstein after his death and commented on the Avenatti case, calling it an illegal 'shakedown'.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Deceased financier accused of sex trafficking. His death by suicide in jail led to a motion to drop charges and ongoing investigations into his co-conspirators and estate.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: Described in lawsuits as Epstein's co-conspirator who assisted in maintaining his sex trafficking ring. Her whereabouts were unknown after Epstein's death.

persons.name: William Barr
persons.context: Vowed to investigate Epstein's death and continue the case against any co-conspirators. Ordered the removal of the acting director of the Bureau of Prisons.

persons.name: Boris Nikolic
persons.context: Named as a successor executor in Epstein's will but stated he had no intent to fulfill the duties and distanced himself from Epstein.

persons.name: Darren Indyke
persons.context: Named as an executor of Jeffrey Epstein's estate in his will.

persons.name: Richard Berman
persons.context: Judge presiding over the Jeffrey Epstein case in the Southern District of New York, to whom the motion to drop charges was addressed.

persons.name: Hugh Hurwitz
persons.role: Acting Director of the Bureau of Prisons
persons.context: Was removed from his position by Attorney General William Barr following Epstein's suicide.

persons.name: Nicholas Tartaglione
persons.context: Former police officer and Epstein's former cell mate who alleges guards threatened him after Epstein's death. He is facing separate murder charges.

persons.name: Bruce Barket
persons.context: Attorney for Nicholas Tartaglione who filed a letter alleging his client was being threatened by jail guards.

persons.name: Kenneth Karas
persons.context: White Plains federal judge overseeing Nicholas Tartaglione's case.

persons.name: Scott A. Srebnick
persons.context: One of Michael Avenatti's attorneys in the Nike extortion case.

persons.name: Jose M. Quinon
persons.context: One of Michael Avenatti's attorneys in the Nike extortion case.

persons.name: Gary Franklin Sr.
persons.context: Avenatti's client, a California youth basketball coach who had claims against Nike regarding NCAA rule violations.

persons.name: Stephanie Clifford
persons.context: Also known as Stormy Daniels, a client of Michael Avenatti from whom he is accused of stealing $300,000.

persons.name: John Pierre Dupont
persons.context: Accused of running a fraudulent political donation scheme and is considered a fugitive after jumping bail.

persons.name: Jesus Prado
persons.context: HIV-positive immigrant suing ICE and individual agents over alleged improper medical care and illegal arrest.

persons.name: Donald Trump
persons.context: Mentioned as a former friend of Jeffrey Epstein and in the context of Michael Avenatti's representation of Stormy Daniels.

persons.name: Bill Clinton
persons.context: Mentioned as a former friend of Jeffrey Epstein.

persons.name: Bill Gates
persons.context: Mentioned as having met with Jeffrey Epstein. His former science adviser, Boris Nikolic, was named in Epstein's will.

persons.name: George Mitchell
persons.context: Named in unsealed court documents as someone an alleged victim was directed to have sex with by Ghislaine Maxwell. He denied the allegations.

persons.name: Bill Richardson
persons.context: Named in unsealed court documents as someone an alleged victim was directed to have sex with by Ghislaine Maxwell. He denied the allegations.

persons.name: Marvin Minsky
persons.context: Named in unsealed court documents as someone an alleged victim was directed to have sex with by Ghislaine Maxwell.

persons.context: Named in unsealed court documents as someone an alleged victim was directed to have sex with by Ghislaine Maxwell.

persons.name: James F. Metcalf
persons.context: Judge in Arizona who released John Pierre Dupont on bail.

persons.context: Arizona-based lawyer who locally represented John Pierre Dupont.

Nikolic was named as a successor executor in Epstein's will, indicating a financial/estate planning connection. Nikolic distanced himself from the role.

events.title: Jeffrey Epstein's Suicide
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein hanged himself in his Manhattan jail cell at the Metropolitan Correctional Center.

events.title: Motion to Drop Epstein Charges
events.description: U.S. Attorney Geoffrey Berman filed a motion to drop the sex trafficking charges against Jeffrey Epstein due to his death.

events.title: Epstein's First Suicide Attempt
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found with neck injuries in his cell, an incident believed to be a suicide attempt. He was sharing the cell with Nicholas Tartaglione at the time.

events.title: Raid on Epstein's Private Island
events.description: FBI agents and NYPD officers raided Jeffrey Epstein's private island in the U.S. Virgin Islands and seized computers.

events.title: Avenatti Motion to Dismiss
events.description: Michael Avenatti's attorneys filed a motion to dismiss the Nike extortion indictment, arguing litigation privilege and First Amendment protections.

events.title: Dupont Released on Bail
events.description: John Pierre Dupont was released on $100,000 bail by a magistrate judge in Phoenix. He later became a fugitive.

events.title: Tartaglione Alleges Threats
events.description: Nicholas Tartaglione's attorney filed a letter alleging MCC guards threatened his client following Epstein's suicide, seeking his transfer to another prison.

locations: St. Thomas (where Epstein's will was filed)
keyFacts: Following Jeffrey Epstein's suicide on August 10, 2019, federal prosecutors moved to drop the criminal charges against him, but vowed to continue investigating his co-conspirators.

Epstein's will, signed two days before his death, showed an estate worth nearly $580 million and named longtime employees Darren Indyke and Richard Kahn as executors, with Boris Nikolic as a successor executor.
Ghislaine Maxwell was explicitly named in court documents as Epstein's alleged co-conspirator in his sex trafficking ring, with her whereabouts unknown after his death.
Epstein's former cell mate, Nicholas Tartaglione, alleged through his lawyer that guards at the MCC threatened him to prevent him from sharing information about Epstein's suicide and jail conditions.
The news clips also cover unrelated SDNY cases, including Michael Avenatti's fight against extortion charges and the fugitive status of John Pierre Dupont.
